image.altText: An adult and a child walking across a pedestrian crossing in a school zone, with the bonnet of a car in the left foreground.

props.synopsis: Canberra mother Veronica Fortune says the road past her local school is an accident waiting to happen. She's written to MLAs about safety improvements and campaigned for adjustments to the roads, but so far nothing has changed.

title.children: Would you accept a 30kph school zone speed limit?

image.altText: A man wearing a white button down shirt, black jeans and large sunglasses walks out of a court building holding papers.

props.synopsis: Canberra 28-year-old Jett Black, who was among a group of detainees that in late 2020 started a prison riot sparked by a lack of cigarettes, no dessert and COVID restrictions, walks free from court.

title.children: Canberra man told to 'make different friends' in prison riot sentencing

image.altText: The ACT Supreme Court towards dusk.

props.synopsis: Depraved and violent torture is how an ACT Supreme Court judge described the actions of a brother found guilty of sexually abusing his two sisters over several years, as he was sentenced to over 16 years in jail.

title.children: Canberra judge jails brother for 'depraved' abuse of sisters

image.altText: Seven teenage boys stand in a circle on an outdoor basketball court listening to a man in a white beanie speaking.

props.synopsis: Menslink workshops are helping young men tackle harmful social expectations, loneliness and anger, by stirring up the toxicity "all around them" and encouraging them to decide what sort of men they want to be.

title.children: Confidential sessions challenging 'toxic' masculinity in teen boys

image.altText: A rabbit outside Parliament House

props.synopsis: Rabbits were introduced to Australia during colonisation, with 'plagues' causing widespread environmental, agricultural and economic destruction. Nowadays the pest is controlled using biocontrol, but experts say without funding the population could soon be out of control.

title.children: The ACT could be looking down the burrow of a rabbit plague

image.altText: A mother holds a snowboard and a toddler who is smiling.

props.synopsis: Towns in the Snowy Mountains rely on tourist dollars during winter, but as the cost of living bites, Aussies are looking for ways to enjoy snow holidays on a budget.

title.children: How Aussies are affording a 'bloody expensive' trip to the snow

image.altText: An aerial photograph of a spreading patch of fire in bushland, with masses of smoke rising from the fire.

props.synopsis: Five years on from the Orroral Valley fire some Bumbalong residents are still rebuilding. An apology in the findings of an inquiry into the fire yesterday was the first time the hardship of residents was officially acknowledged.

title.children: Though not scathing, the inquiry into this devastating fire was needed

image.altText: Donald Trump points at someone with his right hand index finger.

props.synopsis: Key defence figures on both sides of the Atlantic warn the risks to AUKUS run deeper than whether a review finds it is "America first" enough for Donald Trump.

title.children: 'No penalties, no refunds': US quitting AUKUS would leave Australia high and dry

image.altText: Two police officers redirect a driver of a vehicle.

props.synopsis: Police say a member of the public allegedly shot a police officer dead as they approached a house in the state's north-west. Follow updates live.

title.children: Tasmania Police officer shot dead while approaching house

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Senior officer not named out of respect for family

image.altText: Jim Rogers

props.synopsis: There were signs for years that something was wrong, and Jim Rogers's doctor put it down to stress. But when the 55-year-old couldn't silence his phone, his world began to unravel.

title.children: The early signs of dementia that Jim missed for years

image.altText: Construction on Curtis Island

props.synopsis: The exchange of missile fire between Israel and Iran has global markets on edge, but energy stocks lead the local share market higher. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Santos shares jump 12pc on $30 billion takeover bid

image.altText: Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles speaks at a press conference watched by WA Premier Roger Cook.

props.synopsis: Defence Minister Richard Marles has warned defence officials and top brass he's willing to shake up the bureaucracy to ensure it delivers major projects on time. Follow live.

title.children: Marles willing to shake up bureaucracy to ensure timely delivery of major projects

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Richard Marles issues warning to defence bureaucrats over project deliveries
Federal govt planning repatriation flights for Australians trapped in the Middle East
Coalition open to supporting Labor's plan to cut student debt by 20 per cent

image.altText: Anthony Albanese in a suit at a microphone in front of a wall of plants.

props.synopsis: As the Australian prime minister prepares to meet with the US president for their first face-to-face meeting, only one is leading a country where democracy is thriving and the public isn't bitterly divided.

title.children: Australia is having a 'democracy bounce'. Trump could learn a lesson

image.altText: Illustration of a man wearing a cap with electrodes coming out of it, with thought bubbles with different words on turquoise

props.synopsis: Sydney researchers have developed an AI model that can decipher words and sentences from brainwaves detected by a wearable cap. It opens up a new frontier to help patients with cognition, but could also revolutionise how humans interact with computers.

title.children: AI is everywhere and now its being used to read our minds

image.altText: A villa in Bali where three motobikes are parked outside and the entrance is cornered off with police tap

props.synopsis: Zivan Radmanovic was killed on Saturday when two men broke into the villa he was staying in near the Bali tourist hotspot Canggu.

title.children: Bali police retract statement over arrest in Australian man's death in Bali villa shooting

image.altText: Four members of Grammy nominated band Hiatus Kaiyote pose against pink backdrop

props.synopsis: When Australian musician Paul Bender looked into why tracks he hadn't made were appearing on his Spotify profile, what he found was a security exploit that's making AI-generated music scams easier than ever.

title.children: 'Laughable': Aussie artist says scammers flooding Spotify with AI fakes

image.altText: A supplied headshot of Leonard Lauder

props.synopsis: The oldest son of the Estée Lauder founders, who himself turned the company into one of the world's biggest cosmetic makers, has died.

title.children: Cosmetics industry icon Leonard Lauder dies aged 92

image.altText: Thuimb

props.synopsis: Australian tennis champ Ash Barty and her husband Garry Kissick welcome their daughter Jordan into the world.

title.children: Tennis legend Ash Barty announces birth of daughter Jordan

image.altText: Lisa Millar with dogs

props.synopsis: The annual celebration of Australian TV also announces a new award named for journalist Ray Martin.

title.children: Lisa Millar secures nod as women dominate 2025 Gold Logie nominations

image.altText: baby

props.synopsis: A five-month-old girl was taken to hospital after an e-bike rider sprayed a fire extinguisher into a car that was waiting at traffic lights.

title.children: Baby injured after 'horrific' fire extinguisher attack on Sunshine Coast

image.altText: Police cars outside an apartment building.

props.synopsis: A second crime scene has now been set up in Werrington as police look into the death of a woman, whose body was found face down in a reserve at the weekend.

title.children: Police search Sydney home after woman's body found in reserve

image.altText: a burning log

props.synopsis: The felling of what is estimated to be hundreds of tingle trees in a burn last December has sparked fresh calls for a review of prescribed burning in WA.

title.children: Burn that toppled estimated 400yo tingle tree killed 'hundreds more'

image.altText: Australian writer Alistair Kitchen stands holding a laptop he says he was denied entry to the United States

props.synopsis: Melbourne writer Alistair Kitchen was detained for 12 hours at Los Angeles International Airport, had his phone seized and was "interrogated" about his views on the conflict in the Middle East.

title.children: Australian denied entry to US after being grilled on Israel-Gaza views

image.altText: Virgin Australian and Qantas flights listed on an airport departures board

props.synopsis: Qantas, Air New Zealand and a rejuvenated Virgin Australia are putting the pieces into play for what is shaping up to be a torrid summer of competition, that could see travellers come out on top and investors pay the price.

title.children: Travellers to win, investors to pay as airlines prepare for price war

image.altText: cattle tightly in a holding yard in a saleyard

props.synopsis: The Department of Primary Industries says a video of a cow being repeatedly shot at Boyanup Saleyards is not enough for prosecution, amid calls for stronger animal welfare measures.

title.children: Shooting of cow at saleyard 'doesn't meet community expectations', vet says

image.altText: A female doctor carrying a stethoscope.

props.synopsis: A Grattan Institute report has found one in five Australians have been charged an "extreme" specialist fee, as out-of-pocket costs and public waitlists soar.

title.children: 'Left on autopilot': Calls to rethink specialist system after extreme fees

image.altText: A procession and the pirie burning of an ogoh-ogoh for Dark Mofo.

props.synopsis: Ten days of cold nights filled with experiential art, food and fire has come to a close with the burning of this year's Ogoh-Ogoh effigy.

title.children: Dark Mofo comes to a fiery end as Maugean skate Ogoh-Ogoh burns

image.altText: A man with facial hair wearing a high-vis vest.

props.synopsis: Chinese-owned company Landbridge has come out in defence of its operation of Darwin Port, as the federal government negotiates to get the facility back "under Australian control".

title.children: 'There is a right price' for the Port of Darwin but it's likely to be very steep

image.altText: Energy tower with blue skies and fencing

props.synopsis: Australians struggling to pay their energy bills face 'major inconsistencies' in how retailers respond, a survey of financial counsellors has found. The energy sector is lagging behind banking and water when it comes to supporting customers in hardship.

title.children: The worst-ranked energy retailers when it comes to hardship provisions

image.altText: A woman with short hair and a blue shirt looks ahead.

props.synopsis: With more than 100,000 treatment cycles taking place yearly in Australia's growing IVF industry, those with first-hand experience say it's time for changes to increase transparency and simplify regulations.

title.children: IVF mix-ups raise questions about the rapidly growing industry

image.altText: A woman cries with her hands held together

props.synopsis: Authorities locate the ill-fated plane's second black box as the investigation continues, ordering inspections of Air India's Boeing Dreamliners.

title.children: Air India crash remains handed to relatives, second black box found

image.altText: A professionally plated meal featuring purple tomatoes.

props.synopsis: A genetically modified tomato the colour of an eggplant could be available on supermarket shelves as early as next year if regulators approve a bid to grow it in Australia.

title.children: Antioxidant-rich purple tomatoes may soon be on Australian shelves

image.altText: A close-up shot of a ram.

props.synopsis: A ram sold for a world record price of $450,000 back in 1989, but a Country Hour reporter remembers it as the peak before the fall for Australia's wool industry.

title.children: The $450,000 ram and what became of Australia's wool industry

image.altText: A man in a purple blazer leaves a court building surrounded by a media scrum

props.synopsis: A former SA Police detective who repeatedly abused his ex-wife has been jailed, with his victim demanding "comprehensive reforms" in the "ill-equipped" police force that she said ignored her cries for help.

title.children: Former police detective jailed for repeatedly assaulting ex-wife

image.altText: a man looks downward pensively

props.synopsis: When Terry Harper first set foot inside the Sydney Opera House it was an "empty cavern". He would spend a lifetime inside its venues making sure every piano note was perfect.

title.children: Opera House piano tuner can barely play but makes every note perfect
